body:
For now two issues have been spotted:
- https://github.com/bitcoin-core/gui/issues/392 (fixed in https://github.com/bitcoin-core/gui/pull/393, backported in #22629)
- #22623, suggested fix in #22625

Compiled v22.0rc2 on PopOS!20.10 (Ubuntu 20.10) and have been testing the External Signers feature. Noticed some strange behaviors which are summarized here:
* https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/22635
* https://github.com/bitcoin-core/gui/issues/395
* https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/22636

While the version is mostly named `22.0` (or `22.0rc2`), in the splash screen it says `22.0.0` together with a long suffix:
![screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8447873/128418345-45383a21-672b-492b-8b29-b961ff42252f.png)
Unfortunately, I cannot resize the splash screen, so I cannot see the whole suffix, which makes the capped display buggy I think.

But after the GUI has started, when going to menu Help->About Bitcoin Core one can see the whole string I guess: `Bitcoin Core Version v22.0.0-g873fbc745d037ad43570f81e58334c397bc95477`

What's about this long suffix, is that new or is it unintended? And why `22.0.0` here?
@wodry see #22623

Small user issue feedback: Hebastos key cannot be imported from `hkp://keys.openpgp.org` because of missing user id, while some others could be imported from it:
```
gpg --receive-keys D1DBF2C4B96F2DEBF4C16654410108112E7EA81F
gpg: key 410108112E7EA81F: new key but contains no user ID - skipped
gpg: Total number processed: 1
gpg:           w/o user IDs: 1
```
But import was possible from key server `hkps://keyserver.ubuntu.com`.

bitcoin-22.0rc2
Linux 4.19.0-17-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 4.19.194-3 (2021-07-18) x86_64 GNU/Linux
Debian GNU/Linux 10 (buster)

connects to ten Tor nodes with this `bitcoin.conf`, no I2P connections (expected: _zero_ outgoing Onion connections because of singular specification of parameter `onlynet` with value `i2p`):
```
upnp=0
debug=i2p
shrinkdebugfile=1
onlynet=i2p
listen=1
timeout=20000
server=1
maxtxfee=0.001
i2psam=127.0.0.1:7656
addnode=72l3ucjkuscrbiiepoehuwqgknyzgo7zuix5ty4puwrkyhtmnsga.b32.i2p:0
addnode=c4gfnttsuwqomiygupdqqqyy5y5emnk5c73hrfvatri67prd7vyq.b32.i2p:0
addnode=gehtac45oaghz54ypyopim64mql7oad2bqclla74l6tfeolzmodq.b32.i2p:0
addnode=h3r6bkn46qxftwja53pxiykntegfyfjqtnzbm6iv6r5mungmqgmq.b32.i2p:0
addnode=hnbbyjpxx54623l555sta7pocy3se4sdgmuebi5k6reesz5rjp6q.b32.i2p:0
addnode=pjs7or2ctvteeo5tu4bwyrtydeuhqhvdprtujn4daxr75jpebjxa.b32.i2p:0
addnode=wwbw7nqr3ahkqv62cuqfwgtneekvvpnuc4i4f6yo7tpoqjswvcwa.b32.i2p:0
addnode=zsxwyo6qcn3chqzwxnseusqgsnuw3maqnztkiypyfxtya4snkoka.b32.i2p:0
```
@wodry thanks -- do you see an I2P local address in -netinfo or getnetworkinfo (if not, have you installed an I2P router, like i2p-router or i2pd)?

@jonatack No I2P local address with `bitcoin-cli -netinfo`, only Onion local address `....onion     port   8333    score      4`

What must be allowed in firewall for I2P for minimum functionality?
Currently, I have outgoing only TCP 53,80,443,9001,9030 allowed for Tor and UDP 53 (DNS) and ICMP.
Do I need to allow outgoing TCP+UDP to _all_ ports? Read https://geti2p.net/en/faq#ports but not sure.

> No I2P local address with bitcoin-cli -netinfo, only Onion local address ....onion port 8333 score 4

@wodry Do you see 127.0.0.1:7656 in `ss -nlt` as mentioned in step 2 here? : https://github.com/BlockchainCommons/Learning-Bitcoin-from-the-Command-Line/blob/master/15_1_i2p_service.md

@prayank23 Yes, i2pd is listening on 127.0.0.1:7656, the file ~/.bitcoin/i2p_private_key was also created. But no log line "SAM session created." Here the last I2P debug log lines:

```
2021-08-05T22:08:36Z I2P: Creating SAM session with 127.0.0.1:7656
2021-08-05T22:11:36Z I2P: Error connecting to wwbw7nqr3ahkqv62cuqfwgtneekvvpnuc4i4f6yo7tpoqjswvcwa.b32.i2p:0: Receive timeout (received 0 bytes without terminator before that)
2021-08-05T22:11:36Z I2P: Control socket error: not connected
2021-08-05T22:11:36Z I2P: Creating SAM session with 127.0.0.1:7656
2021-08-05T22:14:36Z I2P: Error listening: Receive timeout (received 0 bytes without terminator before that)
2021-08-05T22:14:36Z I2P: Control socket error: not connected
2021-08-05T22:14:36Z I2P: Creating SAM session with 127.0.0.1:7656
2021-08-05T22:17:36Z I2P: Error connecting to zsxwyo6qcn3chqzwxnseusqgsnuw3maqnztkiypyfxtya4snkoka.b32.i2p:0: Receive timeout (received 0 bytes without terminator befor
2021-08-05T22:17:36Z I2P: Control socket error: not connected
2021-08-05T22:17:36Z I2P: Creating SAM session with 127.0.0.1:7656
2021-08-05T22:20:36Z I2P: Error listening: Receive timeout (received 0 bytes without terminator before that)
2021-08-05T22:20:36Z I2P: Creating SAM session with 127.0.0.1:7656
2021-08-05T22:23:36Z I2P: Error connecting to 72l3ucjkuscrbiiepoehuwqgknyzgo7zuix5ty4puwrkyhtmnsga.b32.i2p:0: Receive timeout (received 0 bytes without terminator befor
2021-08-05T22:23:36Z I2P: Control socket error: not connected
2021-08-05T22:23:36Z I2P: Control socket error: not connected
2021-08-05T22:23:36Z I2P: Creating SAM session with 127.0.0.1:7656
2021-08-05T22:26:36Z I2P: Error connecting to c4gfnttsuwqomiygupdqqqyy5y5emnk5c73hrfvatri67prd7vyq.b32.i2p:0: Receive timeout (received 0 bytes without terminator befor
2021-08-05T22:26:36Z I2P: Control socket error: not connected
2021-08-05T22:26:36Z I2P: Creating SAM session with 127.0.0.1:7656
2021-08-05T22:29:36Z I2P: Error listening: Receive timeout (received 0 bytes without terminator before that)
2021-08-05T22:29:36Z I2P: Control socket error: not connected
2021-08-05T22:29:36Z I2P: Creating SAM session with 127.0.0.1:7656
```
Here screenshot of Web interface main page:
![screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8447873/128430068-9aca630f-4f58-4684-986d-e0aeb51a8999.png)

i2pd version 2.23.0   (plain Debian distro install without any configuration)

> 2021-08-05T22:11:36Z I2P: Error connecting to wwbw7nqr3ahkqv62cuqfwgtneekvvpnuc4i4f6yo7tpoqjswvcwa.b32.i2p:0: Receive timeout (received 0 bytes without terminator before that)
2021-08-05T22:11:36Z I2P: Control socket error: not connected

According to my understanding first line in this is printed because there was no response in 1 second from i2p router:

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/39d597d362a2a06d276dd55a152c729c01c1e661/src/util/sock.cpp#L191

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/39d597d362a2a06d276dd55a152c729c01c1e661/src/util/sock.cpp#L250

if(`now` >= `deadline`)

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/39d597d362a2a06d276dd55a152c729c01c1e661/src/util/sock.cpp#L254

`timeout` = `MAX_WAIT_FOR_IO` according to:

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/d8f1e1327f9c2f9fcc804468f6a981580acdf30a/src/i2p.cpp#L160

And `MAX_WAIT_FOR_IO` is 1 second according to:

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/39d597d362a2a06d276dd55a152c729c01c1e661/src/util/sock.h#L19

After allowing TCP+UDP outbound to all ports, it looks better. Now I get log message `I2P: SAM session created`, `bitcoin-cli -netinfo` shows local address `....b32.i2p       port      0    score      4`, and there are outbound I2P connections.

Testing feedback from me so far:
* First I had to do `sudo apt install libxkbcommon-x11-0` for bitcoin-qt being able to start (0.21.1 did not require that).
* Singular specification of parameter `onlynet` with value `i2p` should only allow I2P connections outbound, not Onion.
* `/var/log/i2pd/i2pd.log` shows many errors `error - Identity: Unknown crypto key type 4` which according to [this issue](https://github.com/PurpleI2P/i2pd/issues/1676) is because of too old i2pd version 2.23.0. I would like that Bitcoind should be so conservative that features work on a plain vanilla current distribution release like Debian, without needing to add foreign package repositories.
* I see many log lines `Error connecting to xxx.b32.i2p:0: Unexpected reply to "NAMING LOOKUP NAME=xxx.b32.i2p": "NAMING REPLY RESULT=INVALID_KEY NAME=xxx.b32.i2p"`
* I do not like that it seems that for i2pd it is needed to allow outbound TCP+UDP to all ports, I would like defined ports or at least a defined smaller port range for a more defined situation.
* Great performance boost on bitcoin-qt startup, really lightning fast now :+1: 

Addition:
If adding `onion=0` to the bitcoin.conf shown in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/22634#issuecomment-893825960 I get the strange user experience, that there are now zero I2P connections anymore even after 3 hours running, allthough `bitcoin-cli -addrinfo` shows `"i2p": 10,` which is 2 more than the 8 added with addnode in bitcoin.conf. There are only 3 inbound Onion connections. Wonder why disabling Onion outbound would have an effect on I2P. Edit: On a second test, after having bitcoind run with both Onion and I2P connections for 1h or so, after restart with onion=0, so only I2P network, I got I2P connections right on startup, so works for me now. But nevertheless, I leave the first experience written here, for doc.
I could now also remove the I2P addnode lines from bitcoin.conf, and get I2P connections after restart, I guess the I2P peers are used now from the peer cache.

Thanks for the report!
- We've had reports of i2pd 2.23 (debian stable / buster) not working (https://www.erisian.com.au/bitcoin-core-dev/log-2021-02-10.html#l-491) and of versions starting with 2.24 maybe being ok, and of people running nodes with 2.35+. The latest i2pd release is 2.38, and 2.36 is shipped with Debian testing / bullseye. Edit: The issue with i2pd 2.23 was addressed on our side. I have been retesting i2pd 2.23 and after some initial funkiness (spurious warnings about peers before sometimes finally succeeding the connection) it has been working fairly well, though 2.36 and up seem more solid.
- Regarding seeing outbound onion connections with onlynet=i2p, I was able to reproduce #22647. Configuring with `-onion=0` or #22651 solves it.

I'll look at updating `doc/i2p.md`.

I think it would be better to have the SHA256SUMS file not contain the directory structure. It's unlikely that a user will have downloaded the release into the directory structure that the SHA256SUMS file expects so a command to verify the hash(es) may not work as expected. It also diverges from what we have done previously so existing verification tooling will probably fail.

I've written a fix for this in #22654

@achow101 I have now rewritten my download&verfiy bash script already. It's true that I e.g. do not download into a subfolder "x86_64-linux-gnu", so as you said, I experienced that `sha256sum -c --ignore-missing` does not work. My workaround was just to do `grep <Tarballname> SHA256SUMS` and then `sha256sum <Tarballname>` to be able to do manual visual comparison of the two output hashes (which I did also with the previous SHA256SUM format file, which contained the signature itself). I am not sure if this is good or bad, on one hand I like it that the SHA256SUMS file mirrors the download directory structure, that is clean and I think it would not be feasible to have an SHA256SUMS file in every arch sub dir, because that would require also a signature file for each of them. On the other hand, I agree, that normally one does not download in an arch sub dir. But the latter could be done easily I think, though.

Compiled Bitcoin core v22.0rc2 on Ubuntu 18.04 and have got the TOR changes and I2P tested. Able to connect to v2 TOR addresses for initial block download and v3 TOR addresses as well. Able to run Bitcoin core over I2P, was able to see the connected peers. Worked as expected in 22.0rc-testing-guide for these two tests.

Compiled the v22.0rc2 on Ubuntu 20.04 successfully. 
Tested the Tor changes, the connection of peers got stuck while connecting to Tor V2 peers, I am not sure about the reason, but I tried restarting the node a couple of times and it got working. Worked as expected for the connection with v3 addresses. 
Also was able to run the core on I2P and was able to get the peer info. 
Was able to test GUIX builds and attested the non-codesigned binaries.
@Saviour1001 possibly many node operators are already moving [out of v2](https://blog.torproject.org/v2-deprecation-timeline)

Compiled v22.0rc2 from source on Manjaro Linux successfully. 

- Was unable to connect to Tor v2 peers as already mentioned in this issue (the connection was stuck even after restarting the node and Tor multiple times).
- Was able to successfully run Bitcoin Core over Tor using v3 addresses
- Was able to successfully run Bitcoin Core over I2P

Compiled successfully from source: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/archive/refs/tags/v22.0rc2.zip on Ubuntu20.04 x86_64 GNU/Linux 5.11.0-25-generic

1. Works as expected for tor v2 peers I was getting an empty peer list 
2. Successfully able to connect some of the tor v3 peers 
3. Successfully able to run over I2P after enabling i2pd.service
4. Faced errors on initializing Trezor hardware wallet emulator
```
./hwi.py enumerate
WARNING:root:No module named 'hwilib.devices.keepkey', required for keepkey. Ignore if you do not want this device.
[{"type": "trezor", "path": "udp:127.0.0.1:21324", "model": "trezor_t_simulator", "needs_pin_sent": false, "needs_passphrase_sent": false, "error": "Not initialized", "code": -18}]
```
![trezor_error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47271616/129078667-91bdc1a4-4d5e-489e-b975-2cbe980d27f4.png)

I've been running `bitcoind` with `i2pd` since shortly after it was added to `master`. I also have `tor` enabled, but clearnet is blocked. Initially I only had 2-3 I2P peers, but by now I sometimes see the number of I2P peers exceed the Tor peers. In an average week, I already push out more traffic over I2P than over Tor. Awesome addition to Bitcoin, having a great experience with it so far! 

One thing I noticed is that when the node temporarily loses Internet connectivity and gets disconnected from its peers, Tor is much faster to reconnect once Internet is back. Not sure why that is.

A few comments on what others have said:

> Singular specification of parameter onlynet with value i2p should only allow I2P connections outbound, not Onion.

I think the name `onlynet` is not intuitive. Why would I add _two_ lines named `**only**net` to allow **two** transports/protocols?

> * `/var/log/i2pd/i2pd.log` shows many errors `error - Identity: Unknown crypto key type 4` which according to [this issue](https://github.com/PurpleI2P/i2pd/issues/1676) is because of too old i2pd version 2.23.0. I would like that Bitcoind should be so conservative that features work on a plain vanilla current distribution release like Debian, without needing to add foreign package repositories.

I created the referenced issue (I found this thread via the backlink ð¯ ). Just one comment here, the warning message did not impact functionality in any visible way, and I'm not even sure if they went away after the upgrade or if they've just been replaced with other ones. I still get a bunch of errors and warnings, see a selection below. I assume it's just `i2pd` being a bit too verbose.

Here are my top errors (please note that I use `i2pd` for non-bitcoind stuff as well): https://github.com/PurpleI2P/i2pd/issues/1685

> * I see many log lines `Error connecting to xxx.b32.i2p:0: Unexpected reply to "NAMING LOOKUP NAME=xxx.b32.i2p": "NAMING REPLY RESULT=INVALID_KEY NAME=xxx.b32.i2p"`

I only have around 2 of those per week in my logs. Think it's just some harmless & intermittent failure.

> * I do not like that it seems that for i2pd it is needed to allow outbound TCP+UDP to all ports, I would like defined ports or at least a defined smaller port range for a more defined situation.

I don't know much about `i2pd`, but I think this is implied by the fact that it's a P2P network and node operators are encouraged to choose their own custom listening ports (I guess for censorship resistance?).

By the way, none of the ports need to be reachable from the outside for `i2pd` to work. It's good for the network, but fully optional.

> Tor is much faster to reconnect once Internet is back. Not sure why that is

This is expected (based on my research). I had also tried to list few difference and trade-offs in https://bitcoin.stackexchange.com/questions/107060/tor-and-i2p-tradeoffs-in-bitcoin-core

> I think the name onlynet is not intuitive. Why would I add two lines named **only**net to allow two transports/protocols?

Agree. Maybe we can change it to `net_out` ?

> Agree. Maybe we can change it to `net_out` ?

But it's not just "outgoing", and I think the commands are far too convoluted already. Why can't we just have a bunch of new switches and then deprecate the existing ones over time ...

```
# this is not fully thought through, just illustrating that it could be much easier
nets_outgoing=ipv4,ipv6,tor,i2p # default = ipv4,ipv6
nets_incoming=ipv4,ipv6,tor,i2p # default = ipv4,ipv6
```

Right now there is a huge zoo of commands and it's not clear what network each refers to and how they interact ... see my comments. (I now know most of the answers, but it was not intuitive to figure out at all and I can easily see people misconfigure their `bitcoind`):

```
onlynet=onion # why is this called ONLYnet if it can be combined?
onlynet=i2p # as above
bind=127.0.0.1 # is this still needed if I set "onlynet"?

listen=1 # does this also affect Tor / I2P? Is it just IPv4 or also IPv6?
listenonion=1 # how is this different from "onlynet=tor"?
i2pacceptincoming=1 # why is this not called "listeni2p"?

onion=127.0.0.1:9050 # why is this jsut called "onion" if it wants a SOCKS server IP?
i2psam=127.0.0.1:7656
proxy=127.0.0.1:9050 # what does this do, how is this different from the things above?

server=1 # why is this not called rpc_server ?
```
onlynet only affects outgoing connections; bind/listen only affect incoming.

> onlynet only affects outgoing connections; bind/listen only affect incoming.

Okay see. Luckily I was diligent and set all the above commands, but it could be much more intuitive (see my comments in the code block).

Tested using both built-from-source (Linux Ubuntu 20.04 x86_64 running as a Virtualbox guest on a windows laptop) and binary (MyNode RPi, armv7l, 32-bit):

Tor on the RPi: all the tests (in the testing guide) passed as expected. The node connected to the v2 nodes during IBD (IBD making progress), and connected to a couple of the v3 nodes after adding those to the config.

I2P on Ubuntu x86_64: During IBD, over 8 hours it made no progress downloading blocks. I don't think it had any peers, but I forgot to run `getpeerinfo`.
<details>
<summary>sample logging output</summary>

```
2021-08-18T14:28:45Z trying connection pjs7or2ctvteeo5tu4bwyrtydeuhqhvdprtujn4daxr75jpebjxa.b32.i2p:0 lastseen=0.0hrs
2021-08-18T14:29:07Z I2P: Error connecting to pjs7or2ctvteeo5tu4bwyrtydeuhqhvdprtujn4daxr75jpebjxa.b32.i2p:0: Unexpected reply to "NAMING LOOKUP NAME=pjs7or2ctvteeo5tu4bwyrtydeuhqhvdprtujn4daxr75jpebjxa.b32.i2p": "NAMING REPLY RESULT=INVALID_KEY NAME=pjs7or2ctvteeo5tu4bwyrtydeuhqhvdprtujn4daxr75jpebjxa.b32.i2p"
2021-08-18T14:29:07Z trying connection wwbw7nqr3ahkqv62cuqfwgtneekvvpnuc4i4f6yo7tpoqjswvcwa.b32.i2p:0 lastseen=0.0hrs
2021-08-18T14:32:07Z I2P: Error connecting to wwbw7nqr3ahkqv62cuqfwgtneekvvpnuc4i4f6yo7tpoqjswvcwa.b32.i2p:0: Receive timeout (received 0 bytes without terminator before that)
```
</details>

But after stopping and restarting the client, it quickly added four `i2p` peers (according to `getpeerinfo`) and is now syncing.

Ubuntu x86_64: Started GUI during IBD and the status and progress indications seem reasonable.

I'll update this comment after doing more testing.

macOS 11.4 ARM64 extended functional test result.

![Remote Desktop Picture August 18, 2021 at 12 44 58 PM EDT](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/152159/129938785-36178580-f751-40aa-9749-29d78c798e56.png)

@RandyMcMillan 
> macOS 11.4 ARM64 extended functional test result.

Check the failure output carefully, because it can often happen that there are timeouts because your system is just too busy. This happened for me just now on a few tests when using `test_runner.py`. You may want to try specifying `test_runner.py -j1` (the default is `-j4`). I didn't do that myself; I just used the default (jobs 4), and had a few timeout failures.

And as @hebasto asked, are the results reproducible? I ran the tests that failed for me individually, and they didn't fail.
Yes, with the functional test runner I usually see a few timeouts locally that aren't reproduced when the tests are invoked directly.
You can also make a bash alias to call the test runner with an increased `--timeout-factor` (maybe 4 or 8)?

Compiled the v22.0rc2 on Debian Bullseye (11 x86_64) successfully. 
I2P Tested on mainnet (onlynet=i2p):
-  Basic functionality works (after adding some I2p nodes)
-  Discovery Works (after adding some I2p nodes)
